LTTextBoxHorizontal.LTTextLineHorizontal: I am very pleased to welcome you here at the Bundesbank's
the occasion of the seventh CEPR/ESI
Training Centre on

LTTextLineHorizontal.LTTextBoxHorizontal: Conference.

LTTextBoxHorizontal.LTTextLineHorizontal: lt is important that academics meet with central bank staff. On the
one hand, these meetings can help to convey new ideas to

LTTextLineHorizontal.LTTextBoxHorizontal: monetary policymakers. On the other hand, these ideas should also
be scrutinised by more practice-oriented economists. Such meetings

LTTextBoxHorizontal.LTTextLineHorizontal: also serve the mutual understanding of one another and help to
clear up misunderstandings.

LTTextLineHorizontal.LTTextBoxHorizontal: I consider these meetings especially valuable because academics
should increasingly confront themselves with practical questions and

LTTextBoxHorizontal.LTTextLineHorizontal: day-to-day policy making. ln turn, central bankers are too closely
watched to allow themselves to fall behind the curve of academic

LTTextLineHorizontal.LTTextBoxHorizontal: thinking.
Only a few years ago, the title of this conference would have had a
question mark at the end. This is no Ionger necessary. The euro

LTTextBoxHorizontal.LTTextLineHorizontal: area, with
the highest possible degree of monetary policy
integration, is indeed an economic entity, but obviously not a political

LTTextLineHorizontal.LTTextBoxHorizontal: entity. The political regime consists of a centralised monetary policy

LTTextBoxHorizontal.LTTextLineHorizontal: and decentralised, but coordinated, economic and budgetary
policies. This institutional setting is challenging. lt is a unique but

LTTextLineHorizontal.LTTextBoxHorizontal: appropriate concept tailored to European needs.
We all know, the euro area did not become an economic entity

LTTextBoxHorizontal.LTTextLineHorizontal: overnight. This fascinating development has its roots in a much
broader process initiated in Europe almest half a century ago. The

LTTextLineHorizontal.LTTextBoxHorizontal: Page 2 of 12
Deutsche Bundesbank, 12.09.2003
convergence which has taken place in the run-up to monetary union
and beyend is impressive. However, this process of European
integration is far from complete and is still evolving.
Let me now turn to more recent developments. Naturally, the
conference will tauch upon crucial issues arising after the first five
years of the third stage of European Monetary Union (EMU).
ln order to stimulate the discussion, allow me to make a few
comments from Â· the vantage point of someone involved 1n the
practical sphere of monetary union: I will comment
firstly an the ways the perception of monetary policy within the
euro area has evolved,

LTTextBoxHorizontal.LTTextLineHorizontal: secondly an converging or diverging growth and inflation rates
and

LTTextLineHorizontal.LTTextBoxHorizontal: finally an what we have learned up to now with regard to policy
coordination and the Stability and Growth Pact.

LTTextBoxHorizontal.LTTextLineHorizontal: 1 . Monetary policy
In the past some rather critical statements have been made by

LTTextLineHorizontal.LTTextBoxHorizontal: academics belanging to the Centre for Economic Policy Research
with regard to monitaring the ECB. At times one actually had the
impression that the ECB came off much worse than other central

LTTextBoxHorizontal.LTTextLineHorizontal: banks. These criticisms ranged from those an individual measures
taken by the ECB - or it refrained to take -
to questions of
communication and strategy. Concerns, for example, were voiced
about the role of monetary growth in the ECB's strategy. There were
also many calls for a more precise definition of the term price

LTTextLineHorizontal.LTTextBoxHorizontal: Page 3 of 12
Deutsche Bundesbank, 12.09.2003
stability. Another favourite pastime seems to have been the hunt to
dismantle at last the unpopular Stability and Growth Pact.
Since reviewing its strategy this year, the ECB has been making
efforts to clarify some misunderstandings which have emerged in its

LTTextBoxHorizontal.LTTextLineHorizontal: communication with the public. lt was made clear that with regard to
price stability, the ECB was striving to maintain a medium-term
inflation rate of below but close to 2Â°/o. Furthermore, it was stressed
that money has to be evaluated with respect to the Ieng-term
relationship between monetary growth and price dynamics. The
"monetary analysis" will complement the "economic analysis", which
is morerelevant in the short to medium term.
I have the impression that, in general, these clarifications were weil
received. I hope that the conference today and tomorrow will help to
shed some light on other important issues within the euro area as
weil.

LTTextLineHorizontal.LTTextBoxHorizontal: Business cycles and inflation differentials

LTTextBoxHorizontal.LTTextLineHorizontal: The introduction of the euro was linked to the expectation that the
business cycles of the member states would converge more closely.
Furthermore, a decoupling from
the US business cycle was

LTTextLineHorizontal.LTTextBoxHorizontal: expected since the euro area has only a marginally higher degree of
openness than the United States.

LTTextBoxHorizontal.LTTextLineHorizontal: The diversion of growth rates among member states has declined
recently. Unfortunately this represents a convergence towards

LTTextLineHorizontal.LTTextBoxHorizontal: Germany's stagnating growth figures - and not towards the faster
Page 4 of 12
Deutsche Bundesbank, 12.09.2003
expanding euro area countries, as would actually have been
desirable.
Contrary to expectations at the outset of monetary un1on, the
business cycles of the euro area and the US seem to be still closely
correlated. Economic globalisation has
increased
international
linkages through various channels such as trade, foreign direct
investment flows, globalised
financial markets and
interlinked
business expectations. But the most significant point isthat shocks
to confidence such as the bursting of the high-tech equity bubble

LTTextBoxHorizontal.LTTextLineHorizontal: and the terrorist attacks have hit capital markets to a similar extent
all over the world.

LTTextLineHorizontal.LTTextBoxHorizontal: A Iack of convergence is revealed by the sustained differentials in
inflation among the euro area's member states. lt is true that these
differentials are fairly small in comparison to the first half of the
1990s. However, following a substantial convergence in the run-up
to EMU, inflation differentials widened again.

LTTextBoxHorizontal.LTTextLineHorizontal: Divergent economic developments are apparent in other currency
areas, too, such as in the USA, without monetary policymakers

LTTextLineHorizontal.LTTextBoxHorizontal: being able to address this issue. Monetary policy has to be geared
towards the data for the currency area as a whole. lt cannot address

LTTextBoxHorizontal.LTTextLineHorizontal: regional policy problems. Otmar lssing once coined that quite
succinctly - "one size must fit all!" The member states had to accept
that fact when they joined the third stage of European economic and

LTTextLineHorizontal.LTTextBoxHorizontal: monetary union. lf persistent diverging trends emerge, either they

LTTextBoxHorizontal.LTTextLineHorizontal: have to be accepted, or, if detrimental economic consequences
result, measures need to be taken at the national Ievei. However,

LTTextLineHorizontal.LTTextBoxHorizontal: Page 5 of 12
Deutsche Bundesbank, 12.09.2003
interest rate differentials also reflect the adjustment of the real
exchange rate.

LTTextBoxHorizontal.LTTextLineHorizontal: But I do not want to elaborate much on inflation differentials. This
issue will be covered in depth in tomorrow's policy lecture by my
colleague, Hermann Remsperger.

LTTextLineHorizontal.LTTextBoxHorizontal: Policy coordination and Stability and Growth Pact

LTTextBoxHorizontal.LTTextLineHorizontal: The asymmetry of political responsibilities

LTTextLineHorizontal.LTTextBoxHorizontal: in EMU makes a

LTTextBoxHorizontal.LTTextLineHorizontal: comprehensive system of coordination procedures indispensable. I
believe this is undisputed. The rationale arises from the need to take
account of the spill-over effects from national economic policies.
Consequently, the EC-Treaty obliges member states to consider
national economic policies "as a matter of common concern" and

LTTextLineHorizontal.LTTextBoxHorizontal: subject them to multilateral procedures.
Of all the coordination mechanisms, name recognition is highest for

LTTextBoxHorizontal.LTTextLineHorizontal: the Stability and Growth Pact. The Pact may not be popular in all
places, but at least it is weil known, albeit not weil understood

LTTextLineHorizontal.LTTextBoxHorizontal: everywhere. I will later on try to illustrate why I remain an ardent
advocate of the Pact.

LTTextBoxHorizontal.LTTextLineHorizontal: However, the core coordination instrument are the broad economic
policy guidelines
the principal policy
objectives and measures. They build the averarehing structure for

LTTextLineHorizontal.LTTextBoxHorizontal: (BEPG). They contain

LTTextBoxHorizontal.LTTextLineHorizontal: the more specialised coordination and consultation procedures. The
guidelines make specific recommendations to each member state
and to the Community and are endorsed by the Heads of State or
Government. However, they are politically but not legally binding

LTTextLineHorizontal.LTTextBoxHorizontal: Page 6 of 12
Deutsche Bundesbank, 12.09.2003
and there are no really effective instruments for enforcing their
implementation. Due to the medium and long-term nature of many
recommendations, measuring progress concerning implementation
has become the main focus of the Commission's work.
The specific coordination processes are:
â¢ The Luxembourg process (1997), which aims to create more
employment. lt consists of employment guideÂ·lines which have to
be implemented by "national action plans" on employment and
are monitared by the Commission.
â¢ The Cardiff process (1998), which is intended to enhance
structural reforms in the member states and their multilateral
monitaring to create "peer pressure" among them.
â¢ The Cologne
process
( 1999 ), which
established
a
"macroeconomic
dialogue"
at Community
Ievei with
representatives of governments, ECB and trade unians involved.
This dialogue aims not to achieve an ex-ante coordination of
economic policies, but the exchange of information and views on
economic developments.
These processes were enhanced in 2000 by the "Lisbon-strategy"

LTTextBoxHorizontal.LTTextLineHorizontal: with its "new strategic goal" for the next decade, that is "to become
the most competitive and dynamic knowledge-based economy in the

LTTextLineHorizontal.LTTextBoxHorizontal: world, capable of sustainable economic growth with more and better
jobs and greater social cohesion". A very important conclusion in
Page 7 of 12
Deutsche Bundesbank, 12.09.2003
Lisbon was that no more coordination processes are needed and
that the existing processes should be simplified. lt is also very

LTTextBoxHorizontal.LTTextLineHorizontal: reasonable that the BEPGs now focus increasingly on structural
policies. That can be a vantage point for the coordination processes
to accomplish better-then-expected results in future. Up to now, it
has been difficult to detect a noticeable impact from these various

LTTextLineHorizontal.LTTextBoxHorizontal: coordination processes on the convergence among member states.
Within the framewerk of the Luxembourg process, governments did
their
commitments

LTTextBoxHorizontal.LTTextLineHorizontal: not meet
employment.
Unemployment is increasing again and is not significantly lower than
in 1997. ln keeping with wage autonomy, governments simply

LTTextLineHorizontal.LTTextBoxHorizontal: enhance
to

LTTextBoxHorizontal.LTTextLineHorizontal: cannot impose any guidelines that regulate negotiations between
management and trade unions. Up to now, the Cardiff process has
led to only limited progress, if at all, on structural reforms in larger
economies. The Cologne process seems unnecessary to me. ln my
than
judgement, all

LTTextLineHorizontal.LTTextBoxHorizontal: these processes have been
little more
bureaucratic exercises.

LTTextBoxHorizontal.LTTextLineHorizontal: What are the reasons?
- after convergence efforts in the run up to the third stage of EMU:

LTTextLineHorizontal.LTTextBoxHorizontal: adjustment fatigue

LTTextBoxHorizontal.LTTextLineHorizontal: the willingness for further progress on integration has lost steam
political behaviour has not adapted to the new environment.
The integration of Europe is linked to the readiness to curb national
sovereignty. The Iasting success of the euro cannot be achieved
solely through monetary policy. The success relies as weil on the
support of the fiscal, labour and structural policies of member states.

LTTextLineHorizontal.LTTextBoxHorizontal: Page 8 of 12
Deutsche Bundesbank, 12.09.2003
However, coordination should not be understood as a substitute for
the responsibility of policymakers at
the national
Ievei. The
decentralised approach offers scope for healthy policy competition.
"Best practice" should prevail. Furthermore, from a political-economy
viewpoint, coordination
is an extremely helpful
instrument to
implement unpopular but necessary policy measures at the national
Ievei.
The Stability and Growth Pact is part of the foundation of economic
and monetary union. But some governments act as if they bare no

LTTextBoxHorizontal.LTTextLineHorizontal: overall responsibility for this political project of European integration.
The ongoing debate on so called "reform" or on relaxing the terms of
the pact has already damaged the foundation and will jeopardise the
functioning of monetary union in the medium term. However, it was

LTTextLineHorizontal.LTTextBoxHorizontal: in fact, a great achievement to adopt self-imposed budgetary rules in

LTTextBoxHorizontal.LTTextLineHorizontal: order to support monetary policy and to prevent a repetition of the
problems of the 1970s. Furthermore, the Stability and Growth Pact

LTTextLineHorizontal.LTTextBoxHorizontal: is dealing with the challenges of ageing populations.

LTTextBoxHorizontal.LTTextLineHorizontal: A critical assessment has to be made, I feel, concerning those
initiatives- some of which have already been implemented - that

LTTextLineHorizontal.LTTextBoxHorizontal: aim to refine the rules of the pact. As a result, these rules, which
were originally straighttorward and
transparent, are becoming
increasingly complex and opaque. Even so, the debate is continuing

LTTextBoxHorizontal.LTTextLineHorizontal: down the same road. The proposals contained in the Sapir Report of
June 2003, which would allow an overshooting of the 3Â°/o criterion
not only in "severe recessions", but also given almest any decline in
economic performance, would dilute the Stability and Growth Pact to
the point where the fiscal policy rules are no Ionger recognisable.

LTTextLineHorizontal.LTTextBoxHorizontal: Page 9 of 12
Deutsche Bundesbank, 12.09.2003
I agree with Otmar lssing: the real problern is not any supposed Iack

LTTextBoxHorizontal.LTTextLineHorizontal: of flexibility in the pact, but the failure of some large economies in
the euro area to make use of growth phases towards sound and
sustainable fiscal positions, like others did. The current difficulties
should therefore not tempt politicians to relax the rules of the
Stability and Growth Pact but to apply the rules strictly. The pact is,
after all, not an end in itself. lt is in the very interest of member
states and their people. The consolidation of public finances is
indispensable, not least in view of the to be expected strains and

LTTextLineHorizontal.LTTextBoxHorizontal: burdens on future generations from demographic changes.

LTTextBoxHorizontal.LTTextLineHorizontal: The Stability and Growth Pact should be seen as part of a
comprehensive strategy to avoid pro-cyclical behaviour, to create
sufficient budgetary safety margins and to attain sustainable public
finance. I know it will be difficult to achieve, but I would very much
welcome your support in convincing both the public and politicians

LTTextLineHorizontal.LTTextBoxHorizontal: that the principles and procedures for budgetary policy in the Treaty

LTTextBoxHorizontal.LTTextLineHorizontal: and in the Stability and Growth Pact are vital for the success of
Economic and Monetary Union.

LTTextLineHorizontal.LTTextBoxHorizontal: I believe I am on common ground in stating that from a theoretical

LTTextBoxHorizontal.LTTextLineHorizontal: perspective, the impact of fiscal policy on the economy is rather
uncertain. Empirical evidence generally points to a positive but Iew
impact of an expansionary policy on output. Therefore, the power of
fiscal policy to reduce cyclical volatility er to stimulate the economy

LTTextLineHorizontal.LTTextBoxHorizontal: should not be overestimated.
Page 10 of 12
Deutsche Bundesbank, 12.09.2003
Discretionary fiscal measures have proved to be ill-suited for fine
tuning the economy in the past. Due to time-lags it has often Iead to
a pro-cyclical
impact an
the economy. Moreover, asymmetric

LTTextBoxHorizontal.LTTextLineHorizontal: behaviour in recessions and booms has contributed to deteriorating
public finances in the last decades.

LTTextLineHorizontal.LTTextBoxHorizontal: lnstead, structural reforms directed at improving price and wage

LTTextBoxHorizontal.LTTextLineHorizontal: flexibility and the mobility of labour could strengthen other channels
of stabilisation.
Ta sum up, by ensuring sound fiscal positions and emphasising the
role of automatic fiscal stabilisers in dampening cyclical fluctuations,

LTTextLineHorizontal.LTTextBoxHorizontal: the EC-Treaty and the Stability and Growth Pact form an adequate
framewerk for fiscal policy in monetary union. The pact is not a
curse but a blessing.
And an a personal note, I would like to add that the very constituting
principle of all democracies is the rule of law.
lt means that
government in all its actions is bound by rules fixed and announced

LTTextBoxHorizontal.LTTextLineHorizontal: beforehand. The rule of law lays down the primacy of law over
policy. Governments which da not uphold this principle offend

LTTextLineHorizontal.LTTextBoxHorizontal: against the fundamentals of modern societies and risk a substantial

LTTextBoxHorizontal.LTTextLineHorizontal: lass of confidence. This holds true for Argentina's arrears to the IMF
and for attempts of EU-Countries to not comply with the spirit and

LTTextLineHorizontal.LTTextBoxHorizontal: Ietter of the EC-Treaty and the Stability and Growth Pact.
The latter is especially disturbing, because the rule of law in modern

LTTextBoxHorizontal.LTTextLineHorizontal: societies seems to be a French invention. lt is based an the principle
of separation of powers which was formulated as early as 17 48 by

LTTextLineHorizontal.LTTextBoxHorizontal: Page 11 of 12
Deutsche Bundesbank, 12.09.2003
the great French political philosopher, Montesquieu. Moreover, it
was the French people who first realised this concept in continental

LTTextBoxHorizontal.LTTextLineHorizontal: Europe. A government breaching the law Ieads down the slippery
slope from which escape is extremely difficult to find.

LTTextLineHorizontal.LTTextBoxHorizontal: I would also like to draw your attention to a paper Hermann
Remsperger and I have written on the importance of budgetary rules

LTTextBoxHorizontal.LTTextLineHorizontal: and on the criticism of the Stability and Growth Pact. Up to now
there is only a Germanversion but the English translation is already
in preparation and will be available in a few days on our website.

LTTextBoxHorizontal.LTTextLineHorizontal: My most important task today is to award the CEPR/ESI prize for the
best central bank research paper. Of the numerous papers
submitted, Gert Peersman's paper entitled "What caused the early
millennium slowdown? Evidence based on vector autoregressions"
was deemed to be the best. The paper attempts to answer this
difficult question by academic means. At the same time, the paper
demonstrates to what extent our answers are determined by the

LTTextLineHorizontal.LTTextBoxHorizontal: respective method of analysis used. Mr Peersman, I congratulate
you on receiving this award.

Ladies and gentlernen
I am to speak here today as a central banker on the subject of

LTTextBoxHorizontal.LTTextLineHorizontal: "Inflation differentials in EMU - causes and implications". But is this
subject really relevant to monetary policy? After all, there are
regional and sectoral differences in price developments in every
currency zone.

LTTextLineHorizontal.LTTextBoxHorizontal: ln a market economy, pnce movements reflect principally the

LTTextBoxHorizontal.LTTextLineHorizontal: varying conditions of supply and demand. Why, then, should one
make the inflation differentials in the euro area into a problern in the
first place? What is more, inflation differentials cannot be affected by

LTTextLineHorizontal.LTTextBoxHorizontal: monetary policy directly, since there cannot be any regionally
oriented monetary policy in a currency union. Monetary policy in a
currency union is uniform.

LTTextBoxHorizontal.LTTextLineHorizontal: However, in the short term or even in the medium term, the impact
of monetary policy may be different from one region or sector to

LTTextLineHorizontal.LTTextBoxHorizontal: another and thus inflation differentials could be of relevance to
monetary policy.

LTTextBoxHorizontal.LTTextLineHorizontal: lt is also of relevance, because we would not have expected still to
be having remarkable differences in price developments now that

LTTextLineHorizontal.LTTextBoxHorizontal: the euro is in its fifth year.

LTTextBoxHorizontal.LTTextLineHorizontal: The key question to be asked is "Should something be done to
counteract the inflation differentials? And if so, what?"

LTTextLineHorizontal.LTTextBoxHorizontal: Page 2 of 24
Deutsche Bundesbank, 13.09.2003
I The diagnosis
However, before I go into these questions, I would first like to stress
that I am rather satisfied with the Eurosystem's stability record.
True, the average inflation rate over the past three years from 2000

LTTextBoxHorizontal.LTTextLineHorizontal: to 2002 has been somewhat outside the definition of price stability.
And it has also been a full percentage point higher than during the

LTTextLineHorizontal.LTTextBoxHorizontal: qualification and start-up stage between 1997 and 1999.

LTTextBoxHorizontal.LTTextLineHorizontal: But, whereas the conditions in that early period were extremely
favourable for stabilisation policy, what followed were exchange rate

LTTextLineHorizontal.LTTextBoxHorizontal: and oil price shocks, food crises, a number of increases in indirect
taxes and other things besides.
Even so, it has been largely possible to keep the Eurosystem's
stability promise. That has to be put down as a success.
Admittedly, that is not the case for all the euro-area countries. ln four

LTTextBoxHorizontal.LTTextLineHorizontal: of the original member states, the average annual price rise in the
past three years has been more than 3Â°/o, with the figure in Ireland
being as much as 4 "!ho/o per year. Given rates of increase on this
scale, it is undoubtedly not appropriate to speak of price stability.
ln addition, it has to be noted that, in those countries which already
had an above-average rate of inflation, prices accelerated more
rapidly following the qualification and start-up phase of monetary

LTTextLineHorizontal.LTTextBoxHorizontal: Page 3 of 24
Deutsche Bundesbank, 13.09.2003
union. Forthat reason, the dispersion of inflation rates has widened
again.
ln terms of their range, the inflation differential in the qualification
and start-up stage waÂ·s less than 1% percentage points; later, it was
more than 3 percentage points.
An increase in the spread is also apparent if alternative measures of
dispersion are used. The unweighted standard deviation, say, went
up from about % percentage point to almest 1 percentage point. This
finding is therefore fairly robust, at least if the rates over three years
are averaged.
ln order to understand disappointments about the extent of inflation
dispersion, I would like to call to mind again the Maastricht inflation
criterion: A country is ready for monetary union only if its inflation
rate is no more than 1.5 percentage points higher than the average
rate of inflation of the three countries with the best stability
performance.
ln the convergence and start-up phase, the average annual rate of

LTTextBoxHorizontal.LTTextLineHorizontal: inflation in Austria, France and Germany was 0.8o/o. At that time, the
critical 2.3Â°/o markwas not being avershat by any country.

LTTextLineHorizontal.LTTextBoxHorizontal: ln the following phase from 2000 to 2002, the three countries just

LTTextBoxHorizontal.LTTextLineHorizontal: mentioned again had the lowest inflation rates in the euro area,
although the average was 1.8Â°/o. Tagether with the margin allowed

LTTextLineHorizontal.LTTextBoxHorizontal: by the inflation criterion, this produced a critical value of 3.3%.

II The causes

LTTextBoxHorizontal.LTTextLineHorizontal: lf you now ask how this renewed widening of euro-area inflation
differentials has come about, I would first like to emphasise that, in
my view, it is impossible to identify a singledominant cause. I think it
may be helpful
"disappearing" and
to distinguish between
"reappearing" causes of inflation differentials.

LTTextLineHorizontal.LTTextBoxHorizontal: The convergence-related components of the inflation differentials

LTTextBoxHorizontal.LTTextLineHorizontal: may be described as "disappearing" .3 Convergence in the Ievei of
economic variables necessarily involves temporary differences in
the rates of change in the relevant variables. Borrowing from the
Iiterature on growth, one could speak here in a broader sense of
beta convergence, which tends to result in always the same

LTTextLineHorizontal.LTTextBoxHorizontal: countries showing either high or low rates of inflation.

LTTextBoxHorizontal.LTTextLineHorizontal: ln this context, the direct convergence of prices and interest rates
through arbitrage across regions should be mentioned first. Nominal
convergence has undoubtedly been reinforced by the elimination of

LTTextLineHorizontal.LTTextBoxHorizontal: the residual foreign exchange risk since the beginning of 1999.

LTTextBoxHorizontal.LTTextLineHorizontal: 3 Empirical studies suggest, firstly, that a certain relationships exists between the inflation
differentials in the euro area and the output gaps. Secondly, it is found that prices rise more
quickly in countries with a low price Ievei. lt is thus likely that cyclical and convergence
related factors operate together. See European Central Bank, Inflation differentials in a
monetary union, Monthly Bulletin, October 1999, p 35-44, and later, P Honohan and
P R Lane, Divergent inflation rates in EMU, Papers presented at the 37th Economic Policy
Panel Meeting, 11th/12th April 2003, Athens. Nevertheless, it is shown by J H Rogers,
Monetary union, price Ievei convergence, and inflation: How close is Europe to the United
States? Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System,
International Finance

The dwindling of the risk premta brought about a largely uniform
interest rate Ievei on capital markets. ln some countries, this is likely
to have generated a substantial cyclical stimulus. An important

LTTextBoxHorizontal.LTTextLineHorizontal: factor was the rapid rise in property prices encouraged by the
convergence of interest rates.4

LTTextLineHorizontal.LTTextBoxHorizontal: On the product markets, too, greater price transparency and the
elimination of exchange rate risk have assisted price convergence.
Nevertheless, the euro's contribution to the integration of the product
markets in Europe should not be overestimated either.
What was more important was the opening of the markets as a
result of the Interna! Market Programme. This had already led to a

LTTextBoxHorizontal.LTTextLineHorizontal: streng convergence of prices for traded goods in the first half of the
1990s. ln 1999, according to Rogers, the dispersion of such prices

LTTextLineHorizontal.LTTextBoxHorizontal: had already ceased to be greater than in the USA.s Since then,
there has been hardly any further narrowing in the dispersion of
prices,6 and the dispersion of rates of price change remained
approximately unchanged.
By contrast, the convergence of prices for non-traded goods -

LTTextBoxHorizontal.LTTextLineHorizontal: above all, services- seems to have accelerated. By and large price
increases were higher in countries with below average price Ieveis.

Shock-like exchange rate movements are of major importance for

LTTextBoxHorizontal.LTTextLineHorizontal: short to medium-term price dynamics in the euro area. Although
there are no Ionger any nominal exchange rate movements within

LTTextLineHorizontal.LTTextBoxHorizontal: the euro area, that is not the case vis-a-vis the dollar area.
The direct impact of exchange rate shocks an consumer prices is

and the strength of the pass-through effect. That effect is powerful
and fast for oil products, but very much weaker and slower in the
case of other goods. Owing to differences in the composition of
private consumption, price developments may therefore differ in the
short to medium term even with uniform shocks.

LTTextBoxHorizontal.LTTextLineHorizontal: Permit me to summarise my brief analysis of causes as follows. No

Firstly, the process of nominal convergence, especially in those

European monetary union, created an expansionary stimulus.
Secondly, the real catching-up process of those euro-area countries
with comparatively low productivity also seems to have contributed

LTTextLineHorizontal.LTTextBoxHorizontal: to the inflation differentials.

price developments. Chief among those factors was the varying
impact of the euro's temporary weakness.16

in their competitive position vis-a-vis non-euro-area countries. Euro
area countries which have a below-average inflation rate gain in
general.
The relationship between the destabilising real interest rate effect
and the stabilising exchange rate effect is ultimately an empirical

regard to the wage formation process, should therefore be an

LTTextLineHorizontal.LTTextBoxHorizontal: To my mind, wage policy has a particular responsibility in terms of

LTTextBoxHorizontal.LTTextLineHorizontal: responding to economic shocks which impact directly on prices. A
temporary increase in the general price Ievei - say, as a result of

inflation differentials
from becoming
entrenched.

LTTextBoxHorizontal.LTTextLineHorizontal: ln cantrast to wage policy the possibilities of monetary policy to
counter inflation differentials are very limited. As a policy for the
entire currency area monetary policy is not in a position to distribute
its effects among the participating countries. Hence, it is unable to
exert an influence on the inflation differentials.

Even so, there are two ways in which the ECB takes account of the
inflation differentials and the prevention of deflationary tendencies.
First, the Governing Council has created monetary conditions which
allow adequate scope for real economic growth.
Second, the Governing Council, in its recent clarification of its
monetary policy strategy, spelled out its stability policy objective in
terms of a medium-term euro-area inflation rate of "just under 2%".
Given the current inflation differentials, that definition, in my view,
provides an adequately large safety margin against deflation for all
the member countries. And with this definition the ECB explicitly

LTTextBoxHorizontal.LTTextLineHorizontal: took account of the implications of inflation differentials within the
euro area.24

LTTextLineHorizontal.LTTextBoxHorizontal: Now, please allow me to summarise my talk in five points. First, I
would like to state that regional inflation differentials in a currency
area are a widespread phenomenon. ln the euro area the underlying
driving forces will change over time. The convergence-related
causes will peter out. Thus, recurrent supply or demand-side shocks
will gain in relative importance. Empirical findings from other
countries speak against
the expectation
that
the
inflation
differentialswill simply disappear.
